# The `LoopInfoBase` Class Template Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

This class builds and contains all of the top-level loop structures in the specified function. <a href="#details">More...</a>

## Declaration

<CodeBlock>template &lt;class BlockT, class LoopT&gt;
class llvm::LoopInfoBase&lt;BlockT, LoopT&gt;</CodeBlock>

## Description {#details}

This class builds and contains all of the top-level loop structures in the specified function.

Definition at line 526 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h">GenericLoopInfo.h</a>.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h/#l00570">570</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h">GenericLoopInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### analyze() {#a280d02be3ec3eb6527c1ea944d902775}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class BlockT, class LoopT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>void llvm::LoopInfoBase&lt; BlockT, LoopT &gt;::analyze (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/dominatortreebase">DominatorTreeBase</a>&lt; BlockT, false &gt; &amp; DomTree)</>}>
Create the loop forest using a stable algorithm.

Analyze <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loopinfo">LoopInfo</a> discovers loops during a postorder <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/dominatortree">DominatorTree</a> traversal interleaved with backward CFG traversals within each subloop (discoverAndMapSubloop).

The backward traversal skips inner subloops, so this part of the algorithm is linear in the number of CFG edges. Subloop and Block vectors are then populated during a single forward CFG traversal (PopulateLoopDFS).

During the two CFG traversals each block is seen three times: 1) Discovered and mapped by a reverse CFG traversal. 2) Visited during a forward DFS CFG traversal. 3) Reverse-inserted in the loop in postorder following forward DFS.

The Block vectors are inclusive, so step 3 requires loop-depth number of insertions per block.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h/#l00693">693</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h">GenericLoopInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfoimpl-h/#l00577">577</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfoimpl-h">GenericLoopInfoImpl.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### destroy() {#ae98a33be737ade7a1f27130477b003f2}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class BlockT, class LoopT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>void llvm::LoopInfoBase&lt; BlockT, LoopT &gt;::destroy (LoopT &#42; L)</>}
  labels = {["inline"]}>
Destroy a loop that has been removed from the <code><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loopinfo">LoopInfo</a></code> nest.

This runs the destructor of the loop object making it invalid to reference afterward. The memory is retained so that the <em>pointer</em> to the loop remains valid.

The caller is responsible for removing this loop from the loop nest and otherwise disconnecting it from the broader <code><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loopinfo">LoopInfo</a></code> data structures. Callers that don&#39;t naturally handle this themselves should probably call ‘erase` instead.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h/#l00710">710</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h">GenericLoopInfo.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getLoopsInPreorder() {#a8a10d542acf3418b2a5bfefb351829c0}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class BlockT, class LoopT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>SmallVector&lt; LoopT &#42;, 4 &gt; llvm::LoopInfoBase&lt; BlockT, LoopT &gt;::getLoopsInPreorder () const</>}>
Return all of the loops in the function in preorder across the loop nests, with siblings in forward program order.

Note that because loops form a forest of trees, preorder is equivalent to reverse postorder.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h/#l00592">592</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h">GenericLoopInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfoimpl-h/#l00606">606</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfoimpl-h">GenericLoopInfoImpl.h</a>.

### getLoopsInReverseSiblingPreorder() {#a485097c9e18d87d37388dc46cecd1dc3}

<MemberDefinition
  template={<>template &lt;class BlockT, class LoopT&gt;</>}
  prototype={<>SmallVector&lt; LoopT &#42;, 4 &gt; llvm::LoopInfoBase&lt; BlockT, LoopT &gt;::getLoopsInReverseSiblingPreorder () const</>}>
Return all of the loops in the function in preorder across the loop nests, with siblings in <em>reverse</em> program order.

Note that because loops form a forest of trees, preorder is equivalent to reverse postorder.

Also note that this is <em>not</em> a reverse preorder. Only the siblings are in reverse program order.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h/#l00602">602</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfo-h">GenericLoopInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfoimpl-h/#l00624">624</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/support/genericloopinfoimpl-h">GenericLoopInfoImpl.h</a>.
